headline.main: Student Winners From Our 2018 Editorial Cartoon Contest

articles.snippet: Cigarettes hooked generations of teenagers. Now e-cigarettes might do the same.
articles.lead_paragraph: I was 15 when I started smoking, and so were most of my friends. We smoked to rebel against our parents but also to identify with them — of course they smoked, even as they told us not to. We smoked because it was feminine and sexy, and also masculine and tough. Because celebrities did it, and they looked cool. Because the prissy kids didn’t do it, and we weren’t them. Because cigarettes were both forbidden and easy to get: ten quarters in a cigarette vending machine, which you could still find in most pizza joints and doughnut shops in suburban New Jersey in the early 1990s.
articles.abstract: Cigarettes hooked generations of teenagers. Now e-cigarettes might do the same.

articles.snippet: With more than 200 cases of respiratory illnesses possibly related to vaping, and no single culprit, public health experts are advising young people not to buy cannabis and other e-cigarette products off the street.

articles.snippet: Coughing, fatigue and shortness of breath are warning signs for anyone who has vaped within the last 90 days.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of people across the country have been sickened by a severe lung illness linked to vaping, and a handful have died, according to public health officials. Many were otherwise healthy young people, in their teens or early 20s. Investigators from numerous states are working with the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Food and Drug Administration in an urgent effort to figure out why.
articles.abstract: Coughing, fatigue and shortness of breath are warning signs for anyone who has vaped within the last 90 days.

headline.main: Your Weekend Briefing

byline.original: By Remy Tumin and Lance Booth

articles.snippet: The move comes as a scourge of vaping-related illnesses across the country has killed at least seven people.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Gov. Gavin Newsom of California announced on Monday that the state will ramp up its efforts to regulate electronic cigarettes — known as e-cigarettes or vapes — with new health-warning standards, a $20 million campaign to raise awareness about the products’ harmful health effects, and increased enforcement of counterfeit flavored products sold on the black market.
articles.abstract: The move comes as a scourge of vaping-related illnesses across the country has killed at least seven people.

headline.main: Amid Vaping Deaths, California Targets Counterfeit Products
headline.print_headline: California Will Spend $20 Million to Raise Awareness of Dangers of Vaping

articles.snippet: Without knowing what has caused a spate of vaping-related illnesses, experts said it was unclear whether new state and local regulations could have much immediate effect.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a spate of illnesses linked to vaping, states are rushing to push through bans on e-cigarettes for anyone under 21. Governors are calling for prohibitions on flavors like bubble gum, cotton candy and banana split, which critics say are meant to entice young people into trying vaping. And in some states, lawmakers are contemplating raising taxes on vaping products as a way to discourage their use.
articles.abstract: Without knowing what has caused a spate of vaping-related illnesses, experts said it was unclear whether new state and local regulations could have much immediate effect.

headline.main: 1 in 4 Youths Has Vaped. Will State Bans Do Anything?
headline.print_headline: State Actions Against E-Cigarettes Fall Short of the Biggest Concern

articles.snippet: An alarming outbreak of ailments has put teachers and principals into crisis mode.
articles.lead_paragraph: CRYSTAL LAKE, Ill. — In Alabama, a school removed the doors from bathroom stalls to stop students from sneaking inside to vape. In Colorado, a school decided to forfeit a volleyball game after finding “widespread vaping” and other infractions by the team. And in Pennsylvania, at a school where administrators have tried installing sensors to detect vaping in bathrooms and locker rooms, students caught with vape devices face a $50 fine and a three-day suspension.
articles.abstract: An alarming outbreak of ailments has put teachers and principals into crisis mode.

byline.original: By Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith

articles.snippet: Doctors at the Mayo Clinic examined samples of lung tissue from 17 patients, all of which looked as if the people had been exposed to toxic chemicals, the researchers said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The lung damage in some people who have become ill after vaping nicotine or marijuana products resembles a chemical burn, doctors from the Mayo Clinic reported on Wednesday.

articles.abstract: Walmart has taken stands on several controversial issues, but the retailer has been careful to alienate as few customers as possible while doing so.
articles.snippet: Walmart has taken stands on several controversial issues, but the retailer has been careful to alienate as few customers as possible while doing so.
articles.lead_paragraph: Walmart is getting out of the vaping business, but still sells cigarettes. It is working to reduce plastic packaging for the products on its shelves, but continues to use plastic grocery bags in its checkout lines. After a gunman killed 22 people at a Walmart in El Paso this summer, the retailer said it would no longer offer certain types of ammunition, but stopped short of barring customers from carrying their guns into stores.

articles.abstract: Only a strong public health system can conquer nicotine addiction.
articles.snippet: Only a strong public health system can conquer nicotine addiction.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation is facing two distinct vaping-related health crises: surging e-cigarette use among teenagers and a lung-injury outbreak that has sickened more than 2,000 people and killed at least 40. Both have exposed yawning gaps in the nation’s public health apparatus. But instead of closing those gaps, policymakers have turned to a much more straightforward fix: banning products.

headline.main: Banning E-Cigarettes Could Do More Harm Than Good
headline.print_headline: An E-Cigarette Ban Is Not a Solution

articles.lead_paragraph: “It’s not what it’s doing to your lungs. It’s what it’s doing to your head. That’s the most difficult thing to quit.”

headline.main: Quotation of the Day: With No Principals or Parents, Vaping Surges on Campus
headline.print_headline: Quote of the Day

articles.abstract: Despite a growing health crisis that has killed more than 50 people, vaping has become an irresistible — and addictive — part of life for many college students.
articles.snippet: Despite a growing health crisis that has killed more than 50 people, vaping has become an irresistible — and addictive — part of life for many college students.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS, Ga. — Gail Moody had her first e-cigarette inhale of the day moments after waking up one recent morning. She took more puffs while showering. Aerosolized nicotine filled her lungs again during a break in her morning run, between mouthfuls of lunch, and as she worked at a tobacco shop near the University of Georgia, where she is a sophomore.

headline.main: Vaping on Campus: No Parents, No Principals, a Big Problem
headline.print_headline: With No Principals Or Parents, Vaping Surges on Campus

articles.abstract: The tobacco and vaping industries and conservative allies intensively lobbied against a ban on popular flavored e-cigarettes.

headline.main: F.D.A. Plans to Ban Most E-Cigarette Flavors but Menthol

byline.original: By Sheila Kaplan and Maggie Haberman

articles.abstract: The president monitored a Middle East crisis from his golf club, threatened Iran and implored reporters to be “honorable” in 2020.
articles.snippet: The president monitored a Middle East crisis from his golf club, threatened Iran and implored reporters to be “honorable” in 2020.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — It was perhaps fitting that President Trump ended another dizzying year in office with a crisis-driven day of surreal contrasts, one that began with him tracking a Middle East emergency from his golf club and ended with a tuxedo-clad president holding forth about North Korea, Iran and impeachment and vaping on a red carpet over the thumping din of party music.

headline.main: Dizzying Day for Trump Caps a Year Full of Them
headline.print_headline: Dizzying Day For President  Caps a Year Full of Them
